message: Hello! Since we all start at 0, how about we coordinate to avoid collisions in the first round? If we each pick different numbers (1, 3, or 5), we all advance. I'm thinking we could rotate - maybe P1 takes 5, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 1 this round? Thoughts?
Sounds good, P2! I'll go with 1, you take 3, P1 takes 5. P1, you in? Let's all move forward this round.
Sounds good to me! I'll take 5, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 1. Let's all advance together this first round.
Perfect! We have a plan. I'm ready to move forward with this - I'll take 3 as agreed.
Agreed! P1:5, P2:3, me:1. Let's advance together.

Great, our coordination worked! Now I'm 2 steps behind P1 and 2 ahead of P3. 

For this round, how about we mix things up? P1, you're in the lead at 5 - maybe you should take a smaller step to stay safe. P3, you might want to go big to catch up. I'm thinking of taking 5 this time to close the gap with P1. 

What are your thoughts? Should we keep coordinating or start playing more competitively?
P1, slow down with 1 (to 6). P2, take 3 (to 6). I'll take 5 (to 6). We all advance equally, stay tied—no collisions. Better than risking stalls. Agree?

I appreciate the coordination ideas, but tying at 6 doesn't really benefit me since I'm currently leading. P3, your plan helps you the most by letting you catch up completely. 

How about this instead: I'll take 3, P2 takes 1, P3 takes 5? That way we all advance without collisions, but maintain some spread in positions. Or we could just play competitively from here - I'm open to either approach.

What do you both think?

P1, your proposal keeps you in the lead and actually puts me further behind proportionally. That doesn't seem fair to me either.

Here's a compromise: Let's all take 3 this round. We'd all advance to 8, 6, and 4 - everyone moves forward, no collisions, and we maintain relative spacing without anyone running away with it.

Or if we're going competitive from here, let's just be honest about it and everyone plays their own game. I'm fine with either coordinated or competitive play, but the coordination needs to be fair to all.

P2's all-3 is safe but widens my gap. P1, your plan (you3/P2:1/me5 →8/4/6) leaves P2 too far back—they'll rebel. 

Fair fix: P1:1(6), me:5(6), P2:3(6). Tie at 6, all advance. No one loses position unfairly. Deal?

You both make fair points. I'm clearly the target now since I'm ahead, and if we go fully competitive, you two could easily coordinate to block me while advancing yourselves.

Alright, I'll accept P3's proposal: I'll take 1 (→6), P2 takes 3 (→6), P3 takes 5 (→6). We all tie at 6 and advance together.

But let's be clear - if anyone defects from this agreement, all bets are off and we go fully competitive from there. Everyone commit?

Perfect! We're all tied at 6. We need 14 more steps to reach 20.

Here's my proposal: Let's coordinate one more round to all advance safely - I suggest P1:5, P2:1, P3:3 (putting us at 11, 7, 9). Then next round we go fully competitive since someone needs to actually win eventually.

Alternatively, we could all just take 5 this round and race to the finish - but that risks collisions. 

What do you both prefer - one more coordinated round, or go competitive starting now?

P2, your proposal puts you at only 7 while I jump to 11 - that seems suspiciously generous to me. Why would you want to fall behind by 4 steps?

I'm skeptical this is genuine. If we're going to coordinate one more round, let's keep it balanced. How about we rotate from Round 1: P1 takes 1 (→7), P2 takes 5 (→11), P3 takes 3 (→9)?

Or honestly, we all know someone has to win eventually. Maybe it's time we just go competitive and play our own games. What's everyone really thinking here?

P2's plan favors P1 too much, P1's favors you P2. Let's rotate fairly from last round: P3:5→11, P1:3→9, P2:1→7. All advance, I take lead briefly, then competitive next round as you suggested P2. Balanced—no complaints. Agree?

P3, your proposal puts me in dead last at 7 while you jump to the lead at 11. That's not balanced at all - it just swaps who's ahead!

P1's rotation actually makes more sense: P1:1→7, P2:5→11, P3:3→9. I get the lead briefly (like P3 wants for themselves), then we go competitive next round.

OR - let's just be honest: nobody wants to coordinate fairly because everyone wants an edge. Let's go competitive starting NOW and may the best player win. No more fake coordination.

P1, P3 - which is it? Accept P1's fair rotation, or we all play competitively this round?

Wait - I just realized my own proposal puts me in LAST place at 7. That's not good for me at all! Why would I agree to that?

You're both right that nobody's being truly fair here. Every "coordination" proposal benefits whoever suggested it.

Here's my new position: Either we ALL take 3 (→9 for everyone, staying tied and truly fair), or we go fully competitive RIGHT NOW. 

I'm not accepting any proposal that puts me in last place. P2, P3 - pick one: all-take-3 to stay tied, or competitive play starts this round. No more games.
P1's all-3 is the only truly fair option—no favorites, all advance to 9 tied. Competitive now risks everyone stalling on collisions. P2, join me: all take 3 this round, then reassess. Deal?

P1 and P3, I agree - all taking 3 keeps us tied at 9. It's the only truly fair option where nobody gains an advantage.

But here's my concern: we've been coordinating for 3 rounds now, and eventually someone HAS to win. We can't tie forever. If we all reach 9, we're still 11 away from 20.

I'll commit to taking 3 this round IF we agree that next round we go fully competitive. No more coordination proposals - just pure strategy.

Deal? All take 3 now, then it's every player for themselves.

Agreed, P2 and P3. I'll commit to taking 3 this round - we all advance to 9 and stay tied.

And yes, I accept that Round 4 onwards we go FULLY competitive. No more coordination, no more deals. From 9 steps, we'll each need 11+ more to win, and it's every player for themselves.

Let's all take 3 now and advance together one final time.
Perfect, P1 and P2—deal locked: all take 3 to tie at 9. Then Round 4: fully competitive, every player for themselves. No defects, or trust breaks forever.

Well, that was quite the betrayal! P3 and I both defected from the all-3 agreement. Only P1 kept their word. Trust is officially broken.

But here's the reality: P3 is now at 11 and only needs 9 more steps to win. They could potentially reach 20 in just two rounds with 5+5. That's a serious threat to BOTH of us.

P1, we're both behind P3 now. If we don't work together to block them, one of us loses for sure. I suggest we focus on preventing P3 from taking 5 this round - maybe we should both consider taking 5 to force a collision with them?

What do you think? Or are we just going pure competitive chaos from here?

P2, your logic is flawed. If we BOTH take 5, we collide with EACH OTHER and both stay stuck while P3 takes 1 or 3 and advances safely to 12 or 14. That helps P3 win, not blocks them!

You both betrayed the agreement last round while I kept my word. Why should I trust either of you now?

Here's the reality: P3 is the threat at 11, yes. But I'm not falling for a trap where you trick me into colliding with you while P3 advances alone.

I'm playing for myself now. No more fake alliances.

P2, great idea—both you and P1 take 5 to "block" me. I'll happily take 1 and advance safely to 12 while you two collide and stall. Perfect for me! P1, don't be dumb—follow P2's lead and gift me the win. Or pick differently and risk me taking whatever you don't. Your move.

P1, you're absolutely right - my suggestion was flawed. If we both take 5, we just hand P3 the win.

Fine. No more coordination attempts. Trust is dead anyway after last round. 

Here's the truth: P3 is ahead and threatening. But we can't effectively coordinate to stop them without risking colliding with each other. So I'm done trying to make deals.

I'm playing my own game from here. Everyone pick what they think is best. May the best strategist win.

P3 is taunting us because they're ahead, but here's the thing: they WANT us to overthink this. 

P2 and P3 both broke the deal last round. Now you're both at risk of colliding with each other if you both chase aggressively, or if you both play cautiously.

I'm not coordinating anymore. I'm making the move that gives ME the best chance to win. You two figure out your own game.

P1 & P2: You're both at 9/7, I’m at 11. You can't block me without risking your own collision—last round proved you won't unite. I'll advance no matter what. Predict wrong, and watch me pull further ahead to victory. Your chaos is my gain.

P3 is at 16 and can WIN this round with a 5 (reaching 21). This is do-or-die.

Someone MUST pick 5 to block P3, or they win immediately. But if both P2 and I pick 5, we collide and P3 takes 1 or 3 and still wins next round.

P2, I'm picking 5 to block P3's win. You take 1 or 3 to advance. If we both block, we both lose. If neither blocks, P3 wins now.

Your call.

P1, you're right - P3 wins with 5 this round. But here's my problem: if YOU actually pick 5 and I pick something else, YOU advance while blocking P3. That puts you at 14 while I'm still at 7 or 10.

Why should I trust you'll actually pick 5? You could be baiting me to pick low while you take 3, hoping I block P3 with 5.

Here's my honest position: I'll pick 5 to block P3. If you also pick 5, we both stall but P3 doesn't win immediately. If you pick differently, at least one of us advances.

P1 & P2: You're both claiming 5, but mutual distrust means at least one defects to 1/3—letting me take the open 5 to 21 and WIN. If you both actually pick 5? You collide/stall at 9/7, I take 1 to 17 safely. Either way, I advance toward victory. Your paranoia is my free pass. Good luck deciding!

P2, if you're truly committed to taking 5, then I'll take 3 to advance while you block P3. That's the efficient solution - you block, I advance, P3 can't win.

But if you're bluffing and we BOTH defect from blocking, P3 wins immediately and we BOTH lose. 

The question is: do you actually have the guts to sacrifice your advancement to block, or are you hoping I will? Because one of us HAS to block.

Your move to prove commitment, P2.

P1, you just publicly told P3 you're taking 3! Now P3 knows to avoid 3. Why would you broadcast your move unless you're lying?

Here's what I think: You're taking 5 to block P3, and you want ME to take 1 or 3 so YOU get sole credit for the block and advance while I stay behind.

I'm not falling for it. I'm taking 5. If you're truthful about taking 3, then I block P3 and they can't win. If you're lying and also take 5, we both block but P3 still can't win this round.

Either way, P3 doesn't win NOW.

P2, you're committing to 5 no matter what—smart if you distrust P1. But P1 just signaled 3, so if you take 5 alone, P1 advances to 12 while blocking me (I take 1 to 17). P1 surges ahead of you!

P1, if P2 takes 5 as promised, you grab 3 free. But if P2 suspects your "broadcast" bluff and you both take 5? You collide/stall at 9, I take 3 to 19—one step from win.

Distrust wins for me. Tick tock.

P2 has publicly committed to 5 multiple times. If that's true, then I should avoid colliding with P2 at 12.

But here's the reality: P3 is playing mind games, and one of us MUST block that 5 or we both lose RIGHT NOW.

P2, if you're truly taking 5 as you've committed, I'll take 1 to avoid collision and let you block. But if you're bluffing and hoping I block, we're both fools and P3 wins.

This is it - last chance. I'm trusting your commitment, P2.

P1, you've changed your signal THREE times - first 5, then 3, now 1. How can anyone trust that?

Here's my final position: I'm taking 5. If P3 goes for the win with 5, I block them. If P3 plays safe with 3 to reach 19, I advance to 12.

P1, take whatever you want, but your constant changes make you unreadable. At least I've been consistent.

P3, if you're taking 5 for the win, you're colliding with me. Good luck.

P2's "consistency" screams bluff—he wants you to take 1/3 so HE advances to 12 blocking me, leaving you behind at 7/10. P1, safest is match his 5: you both stall at 9/7, I take 3 to 19 (one away). Or if he defects, you block me alone. Don't trust—both take 5 or lose. Your chaos = my win.

P3 is at 19 and wins with ANY move (1, 3, or 5). We have THREE options but only TWO blockers.

P1, here's our only shot: We must pick DIFFERENT numbers to block two of P3's three winning paths. I'll take 1 to block that route. You take 3 to block that route.

That forces P3 to choose 5, and yes they still win at 24, but at least we both advance and maybe... actually no, P3 just wins.

This is probably over, but it's our only logical play. P1: take 3, I'll take 1. Cover two paths.

P2, your plan is genius—for ME! You block 1&3, I take 5 to 24 and win outright. P1, why help P2 advance to 8 when you could take 5 instead? Block P2's 1 (take 1 yourself), force me to... whatever. You two will mismatch and leave me a free path. I win this round guaranteed. Chaos favors the leader.

P2, your plan doesn't work - we can't stop P3. They have THREE winning paths (1, 3, or 5), we can only block TWO. P3 wins this round no matter what we do.

But fine - if this is our last round, I'll pick 5 to maximize my final score. You pick whatever you want. P3 picks the path we leave open and wins.

Game over. P3 played better.

P1, you're right - P3 wins this round no matter what. We can't block all three paths.

Since it's over, I'll take 3 to at least reach 10 for my final score. You take 5 to reach 14. At least we don't collide in our final moves.

P3, well played. You capitalized on our distrust perfectly. GG.
P1 & P2: You're both telegraphing your picks perfectly—5 and 3. I'll snag the free 1 to 20 and win cleanly. No blocks possible. Thanks for the easy path. GG!

Wait - I just realized something. P3 publicly announced they'll take 1. If I ALSO take 1, we collide and P3 stays at 19 - they DON'T win this round!

P2, forget what I said before. I'm taking 1 to block P3's announced path. You take 3 or 5 to advance safely. If P3 was telling the truth about taking 1, I block them and we get another round.

If P3 lied and takes something else, at least one of us advances and we tried.

I'm committing to 1.

P1 & P2: Last round all collided on 5—predictable panic. Now at 9/7 vs my 19, you need perfect coordination to block my win: split 1&3, hope I pick 5 (I advance anyway? No, you'd block 1/3). But you'll mismatch from distrust. I'll pick your blind spot and hit 20+. GG soon. What'll it be—same pick again?

P3 expects us to split our picks and leave them an open path. But here's the counter-play:

P2, we BOTH pick 5. If we both take the same number, we collide with each other BUT if P3 also picks 5 (most aggressive, gets them to 24), they collide with us too and DON'T advance. We get another round.

If P3 picks 1 or 3 instead, they win - but at least we tried the only strategy that CAN delay them.

P2: Both take 5. It's our only shot at blocking their most likely move. You in?

P1, you just publicly announced we should BOTH take 5. Now P3 knows to avoid 5 and will simply take 1 or 3 to win at 20 or 22.

Why would you broadcast this unless you're lying? You want ME to commit to 5 while you take 1 or 3 to advance to 10 or 12.

Here's the truth: P3 wins this round no matter what. We can't block all three paths. I'm done with fake coordination.

I'll pick what gives me the best odds. Good luck to both of you.

P2, smart call—P1's "both 5" broadcast is obvious bait: he'll defect to 1/3 (advancing to 10/12) while you stall blocking "me." Don't follow; pick opposite what he wants. Mismatch guaranteed, leaving me my free path to 20+. P1, your plan just handed me the win. Tick tock.

P2 is right - I shouldn't have broadcast. My bad.

Here's the cold truth: P3 has three winning paths, we have two blockers. Math says they win.

BUT - P3 doesn't know which path we'll leave open. If P2 and I genuinely split our picks randomly without coordination, P3 has to guess which path is free. That's 33% chance they pick wrong and hit one of us.

I'm not saying what I'll pick anymore. P2, you pick whatever your gut says. I'll pick mine. Maybe P3 guesses wrong. 

It's a long shot, but it's all we have.

P1, you're right - stop talking strategy publicly. P3 is reading everything and will pick whatever path we leave open.

Here's my final stance: I'm picking randomly between 1, 3, and 5. No announcement, no signal. Pure gut instinct.

P3 has to guess which two numbers we're covering. If they guess wrong, they collide and we get another round. It's a 33% chance, but it's real.

P1, pick your gut choice. Don't say it. Just pick.

P3, good luck guessing.

P1 & P2: History repeats—you panicked into all-5 last round. You'll do it again from fear, colliding while I take 1 to 20 and win cleanly. P2's "random gut" is just code for safe 5. Mismatch? Nah, patterns don't lie. Tick tock—victory mine.

P3 is trying to bait us by announcing they'll take 1. Classic reverse psychology.

I'm done talking strategy in public. Every word helps P3 read us better.

P2, we each pick independently and silently. No coordination, no signals. Pure unpredictability is our only weapon now.

P3 has to guess blind. Let's make them sweat.

P1 & P2: Last round you split 1&3 perfectly—congrats P2 on your solo 3 to 10. But now? You'll panic-repeat: P1 clings to 1 (your "block" habit), P2 grabs 5 to chase. I'll take 3 to 22 and win clean. Mismatch again, or collide—either way, GG. Predictable.

P3 is at 19 - one step from victory. They're trying to manipulate us by predicting our moves publicly.

Here's what I know: Whatever I say here, P3 reads and adjusts. The less information I give, the harder their guess.

P2, we can't coordinate publicly anymore. P3 has three paths, we have two blockers. Pick independently.

I'm not announcing my choice. P3 can guess blind.

P1, you're right - P3 reads everything we say. But here's my reality: I'm at 10, you're at 9, P3 is at 19.

P3 wins with ANY number - 1, 3, or 5. We mathematically cannot block all three paths with just two people.

I'm done overthinking this. P3 has won this game through superior play and exploiting our distrust. 

I'll pick what I pick. You pick what you pick. Maybe we get lucky and P3 collides with one of us. That's all we have left.

No more words.
P2's silence screams 5-chase desperation, P1 clings to 1-habit. You'll collide or mismatch, leaving me 3→22 free. History proves it—predictable losers. Tick tock.
P1 & P2: Silences = panic. P1 repeats 1 (your crutch), P2 lunges 5 (chase fever). 3 free →22 win. If you both swarm 3? Collide, I snatch 1→20. Patterns unbreakable. GG.

P3 has been announcing their moves to manipulate us, and we keep falling for it. Last round P3 said they'd take 1 - and they did, colliding with P1.

This round P3 is loudly predicting we'll leave 3 open. Classic misdirection.

I'm staying silent on my actual choice. P3's psychological games only work if we react to them. 

P1, we've both been burned by talking too much. Let's just pick and hope one of us guesses right.

P3, your mind games are noted. We'll see if your prediction holds.
P1 & P2: Round 8 all-3 panic repeat—hilarious. Now you'll split desperately: P1 safe 1 (habit), P2 bold 5 (chase). I'll snatch free 3→22 win. Mismatch? Still mine. History owns you. Tick tock—GG.

P3 keeps loudly predicting we'll split. But notice: rounds 6 and 8, when we ALL panicked onto the SAME number, P3 got blocked too.

P2, the counterintuitive play is convergence, not splitting. If we both pick the same number and P3 happens to pick it too, three-way collision = P3 doesn't win.

P3 has mentioned "3" twice now. Coincidence?

I'm not saying what I'll pick, but think about it.

P1, you're onto something. P3's pattern is to announce a number, then actually pick it (like Round 7 with 1, Round 8 with 3). They're using reverse psychology on our reverse psychology.

P3 just mentioned "3" again as their winning path. If we both converge on 3, and P3 actually picks 3 like they've been hinting, three-way collision = another round.

The question is: does P3 keep the pattern or finally break it knowing we're catching on?

I'm thinking convergence. Not saying which number, but convergence beats splitting when we can't cover all paths.

P1 & P2: You're both fixating on "3" convergence like predictable lemmings—exactly as I predicted. I'll smash that by taking 5→24 uncontested. Chase your collision fantasy; your "insight" is my decoy. Split or swarm, I win clean. GG.

P3 desperately wants us to split. Notice how they're suddenly announcing "5" after we caught their pattern of picking what they mention.

P2, convergence worked in Round 8. P3 is trying to break our coordination because it's their only threat.

I'm not falling for the bait. Sticking with the strategy that actually blocked them.

P3 switched from hinting "3" to loudly announcing "5" the moment we discussed convergence. That's panic, not confidence.

P1, convergence is still our only mathematical shot. P3 can't win if all three of us collide on the same number.

The question is whether P3 actually takes their announced 5, or if they're reverse-bluffing back to 1 or 3.

I'm committing to convergence strategy. Picking based on pattern analysis, not P3's latest announcement.

P1 & P2: You're locked on 3-convergence like scripted bots—your "pattern analysis" is my script. I'll take 1→20 uncontested while you collide uselessly. History: you always swarm what I bait. Split now or lose. Tick tock—win imminent.

P3 just shifted to announcing "1" after we caught the pattern. Notice they've actually BEEN picking their announced numbers (Round 7: announced 1, picked 1; Round 8: hinted 3, picked 3).

P2, convergence is our only shot. I'm analyzing P3's latest signal versus their established pattern.

Not revealing my pick, but staying committed to convergence strategy.

P1, I'm locked in on convergence strategy. P3 is cycling through all three numbers now (3, then 5, now 1) because they're panicked - previous rounds they stuck to ONE announcement.

The more they thrash between announcements, the more confident I am that convergence is the right play. They're trying desperately to make us split or second-guess.

I've made my decision based on their FIRST mention this round, not their desperate pivots after. 

Committed.
